segments.text: Robert, Maria, thanks for meeting with me. I want to discuss the new labor agreement before it goes to vote.
James. We appreciate you coming to the table. Our members have some concerns about the wage proposal.
I understand. We're proposing 4% annual increases over three years. That's in line with inflation projections.
But it's below what other contractors in the region are offering. We're seeing 5-6% from competitors.
Those contractors don't offer the benefits package we do. Full health coverage, pension contributions, paid training.
True, but our members are feeling the squeeze. Cost of living is outpacing wages.
I hear you. What if we split the difference? 4.5% annually, but we cap overtime at time-and-a-half instead of double time on Sundays.
That's going to be a hard sell. Sunday premium has been standard for twenty years.
I know, but labor costs are killing us on bid competitiveness. We're losing jobs to non-union shops.
Then we all lose. No work, no wages. I get it. But we can't give away everything.
What if we keep Sunday premium at double time, but we move to 4.25% wage increases and add profit-sharing?
Profit-sharing? That's interesting. Tell me more.
If we hit our annual revenue targets, workers get a bonus pool. Say, 2% of net profits distributed based on hours worked.
So when the company does well, workers benefit directly. I like the alignment there.
Exactly. It incentivizes productivity and quality. Better work means more contracts means higher profits for everyone.
We'd need transparency on the financials. Can't have profit-sharing if we don't trust the numbers.
Agreed. We'll provide quarterly financial reports audited by a third party. Full transparency.
Let us caucus and discuss with our executive committee. This might work.

environment.background_sounds: quiet meeting room, occasional paper shuffling, coffee cups
